item.title: Game Design [2]: Why People get Bored?
item.description:
Learning is awesome. It gives you a hit of endorphins, it gives you goosebumps all over your body, it makes your brain go wild.

The problem with learning is, once you‚Äôve learnt something, that‚Äôs it.

You can‚Äôt unlearn something. Sure, you can forget it, but you can only get that hit of endorphins the first time around.

That‚Äôs why we are always learning new stuff. We get bored of what we already know, so we look for something new. We are voracious learners. We get a subject, we learn everything we want to learn about it, and then we dispose of it.

Why People get Bored?

‚ÄúI already know it!!‚Äù

That‚Äôs how some gifted children feel in their traditional schools, or how a senior university student feel the last months of class before graduation.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs nothing new you can teach me!!‚Äù

And they are right.

Let‚Äôs take at look a classic children games:

  • A game like Catch teaches us Physical Coordination.
  • A game like Rock, Paper, Scissors teaches us Chance.
  • A game like Chess teaches us Strategy.
  • A game like Tic, Tac, Toe teaches us Pattern Recognition.

This is obvious for adults. But when you are a kid, these games are helping youe brain develop all sorts of skills without you even knowing.

The last game Tic, Tac, Toe has a very interesting characteristic. It‚Äôs considered a futile game. This means that if both players take the most optimal move, the game will always end in a tie.

item.title: Game Design [1]: What is a Game?
item.description:
The other day I finished A Theory of Fun for Game Design by Raph Koster and I found it very interesting. It articulates what most player feel when we‚Äôve been playing games for a long time.

I liked it so much that I‚Äôm going to give you my thoughts on it. Not a review nor a critique, but something on the lines of a school appointment in which you have to read One Hundred Years of Solitude and later take a test on it, and you follow the general structure and share the points that stuck to you the most.

I will try to be broad and talk about general game design, but this series will be centered in videogame design.

Before we start, you can get the book on Amazon.

What is a Game?

Games are real life.

Sounds like a pretty cheap explanation, but don‚Äôt panic, it will make sense at some point.

Try and remember the first game you played as a child. The very first one you can remember playing as a little kid.

Good, in my case it‚Äôs probably hide and seek. I remember playing it at my nursery school with other kids when I was around 2~3.

Now, let‚Äôs look for an explanation for this. Why do children play to hide from each other?

Let‚Äôs go way back in time to when the human kind lived in caves and hunted for a living. Kids probably played hide and seek as much as kids do now, because it‚Äôs training a basic instinct for humans. Survival. Whether they are hiding from a wolf or a human from another tribe.

Games like hide and seek train us for very real life situations and teach us very real life skills.

  • Running.
  • Tracking.
  • Hiding.
  • Observation.
  • Ability to stay silent.

These are all useful skills. May it be 20.000 years ago or in 2018.

Games have the intrinsic value of teaching us skills in a controlled environment. Games are practice.

Let‚Äôs go back to the ‚ÄúGames are real life‚Äù quote and let‚Äôs be a little more accurate.

Games are real life with lower stakes.

In the next post I‚Äôll be covering the subject of Boredom on Games.

item.title: Jekyll Blog Tutorial
item.description:
Simple Jekyll Blog with Github Pages.

If you want to create a simple, static personal blog, Jekyll and Github Pages are one of the best solutions.

But first, what is Jekyll?

Jekyll is a simple, blog-aware, static site generator.

This means that you write your posts with simple Markdown text and Jekyll converts it to rich and formatted HTML code. Jekyll will stitch your post‚Äôs contents with all the templates and components, and generate a static website, which you can upload to Github Pages (For free!).

Jekyll is a Ruby Gem. A library programmed in Ruby, so you are going to need to install a Ruby environment if you don‚Äôt already have it.

Installation

I‚Äôm using Windows, which makes the installation a little harder than on Linux/MacOS. If you are using one of those, here‚Äôs a link to the official documentation.

1- Download and install RubyInstaller.

2- Open a command prompt and type:

gem install jekyll bundler

This should take a little while. Click here to learn a little bit more about Bundler.

Type this to check if Jekyll has installed properly:

jekyll -v

3- Create a new Jekyll website:

// Creates a new Jekyll project
jekyll new jekyll-test

// Go to the new directory
cd jekyll-test

// Serves the new Jekyll project on http://localhost:4000
jekyll serve

Using a Theme

Cool. You have a Jekyll project running. But let‚Äôs go a little further. You could build the entire website on your own (and, if you have the time, DO IT!), but there are a ton of Jekyll themes made by the good people of Github.

themes.jekyllrc.org has a great number of themes from Github, find one you like and fork it or download it.

I‚Äôve chosen Travelogue for this demonstration, but feel free to use the one you like the most.

If the theme you are using has dependencies, you may need to install them:

bundle install

You can update your dependencies if you want with:

bundle update

Project Structure

Now, let‚Äôs take a look a the project‚Äôs folder structure

_config.yml

Holds most of the page‚Äôs configuration data and global variables.

_includes

Contains small, reusable pieces of code. Think web components. (Head, footer, profile card, etc.)

_layouts

These are page templates that can contain the different pages, normally separated by page type. (Post, category, contact page)

_posts

Is the folder where you will write your posts. These files must be named YEAR-MONTH-DAY-TITLE.markup/markdown.

_data

A static database that all your pages have access to. You can put .yml, .json and .csv files here!

_sass

Can hold multiple .scss files that will be processed into a single minified .css file.

_assets

Folders and files here will be passed without change when the site is processed. Think .js libraries and images.

_site

This is where the fully built, static page will be output once you build it with:

jekyll build

Liquid Attributes

If you go and take a look at any file in the _layouts folder you will see code similar to this:

  
  {% if page.reading_time %}
    <p class="post-reading-time">~
        {% capture words %}
          {{ content | number_of_words | minus: 180 }}
        {% endcapture %}
        {% unless words contains "-" %}
          {{ words | plus: 180 | divided_by: 180 | append: " min" }}
        {% endunless %}
    </p>
  {% endif %}

So what‚Äôs with all these curly brackets??

These are attributes used by the Liquid Template Engine, an open source template language written in (you guessed it) Ruby.

This engine allows you to reference configuration, variables and data from anywhere on the website. And even add logic to your code. Let‚Äôs take a look a the previous code block and add a few comments.

  
  # 'page' references the global file _config.yml
  # If the global variable reading_time is set to 'true'
  {% if page.reading_time %}
    <p class="post-reading-time">
      {% capture words %}
        # Capture is a Liquid's function...
        # It will store the result of the block in a variable..
        # Without rendering it.
        # You can use pipes '|' in Liquid
        # Just like you can do on Linux
        # content: the post's content
        # number_of_words: Liquid's function...
        # Returns the number of words of the parameter.
        # minus: substracts value from the parameter
        {{ content | number_of_words | minus: 180 }}
        # Translated to non-Ruby, this would look:
        # number_of_words(content) - 180;
      {% endcapture %}
      # Ruby has really cool grammar!
      # Unless 'words' contains a minus symbol.
      {% unless words contains "-" %}
        # We will add 180 (what we substracted) and divide by 180
        # Probably the number of words/minute the author found appropiate.
        # And we will append ' min' to 'words'.
        {{ words | plus: 180 | divided_by: 180 | append: " min" }}
      {% endunless %}
    </p>
  {% endif %}

Just by context, we learn that this block of code shows, on every post, the aproximate time in minutes it will take the reader to finish it.

Deploying on Github

Deploying on Github is very easy. You are really just pushing a repository, Github does the rest.

  1. Build the proyect with: 
    jekyll build
  2. Create a repository on Github named ‚Äòyour-user-name-here.github.io‚Äô. This will be your website‚Äôs URL.
  3. Push the contents of _site to the repository.
  4. Go for a coffee while Github‚Äôs servers do their thing.
  5. You‚Äôre done!

A Few Tips

  • Markdown can be hard to remember when starting your Blog. Here‚Äôs a great cheet sheet to remember the basics while you write your posts.

  • If you don‚Äôt like the github.io domain on your blog‚Äôs URL, you can purchase and use a custom domain. Here‚Äôs how to do it.
